messageBody:
Hi Moira,

There are two separate issues here:
1) A standard ASCII representation of QS would (a) facilitate online
discussion and (b) provide an easy way to exchange QS documents in
plain text.
2) Any individual can create a personal keyboard layout to optimize
typing effort and/or mnemonic functions of key assignments. (For
example, I greatly increased my typing speed when I switched from the
Qwerty to the Dvorak keyboard layout. It took a few months to reach
full speed, but it was well worth it.)

I'd be happy to work with you to create a keyboard layout that suits
you. One option, should we go ahead with QS-SAMPA, would be for me to
create a layout for you that eliminates the change. You could continue
typing exactly as you do now. On the other hand, once we've opened up
the possibility, your creativity is set free--you can really consider
what keyboard assignments would be best for you personally. For
example, you might want to determine the most frequently used QS
letters and assign them to the home row on the keyboard. Or you might
want to cluster vowels together on one side of the keyboard and
consonants on the other (a la Dvorak). Whatever you want to do, we can
do it.

I fully understand your concern that we not get into an endless cycle
of changing the standard every time a font designer thinks up some
quirky new system. My hope is that QS-SAMPA will be adopted as an
enduring standard.

Ted
